unit.title: Poetry & Expression: Find Your Voice
unit.overview: Learners explore poetry as a joyful, meaningful form of expression. They study rhythm, rhyme, images, and sound devices; practise figurative language; and craft, revise, and perform their own poems. Short, interactive lessons minimise fatigue. Moral themes highlight gratitude, humility, and care for others, with British English conventions.
competencies: Identify rhyme schemes and basic rhythms in short poems.
Explain and use simile, metaphor, and personification.
Recognise sound devices (alliteration, assonance, onomatopoeia) and their effects.
Write, revise, and present an original 8–12 line poem with clear imagery and theme.
Perform a poem with appropriate pace, intonation, and confidence.
values_morals: Gratitude for everyday blessings; empathy for others.
Use words to uplift and encourage (Ephesians 4:29).

lessons.title: Poetry Basics: Rhythm & Rhyme
objectives: Feel basic rhythm by clapping syllables and stresses.

vocabulary.definition: A group of lines forming a poem section.
A pattern of rhyme marked with letters (e.g., ABAB).
The pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables.

lessons.moral_link: Poetry can celebrate gratitude and peace.

content_blocks.body: Mark the last words of each line with letters to find the rhyme scheme. Clap to feel the rhythm.

content_blocks.caption: Clap along to feel syllable beats.

rhyme_tag.prompt:
Label the rhyme scheme: 
Line1: home 
Line2: fine 
Line3: roam 
Line4: time

quick_check.q: A group of lines in a poem is called a:

lessons.title: Figurative Language: Simile, Metaphor, Personification
objectives: Explain the difference between simile and metaphor.
Write two original lines using personification.

vocabulary.definition: Comparison using 'like' or 'as' (e.g., brave as a lion).
Direct comparison without 'like' or 'as' (e.g., Time is a river).
Giving human qualities to non-human things.

lessons.moral_link: Use images that honour people and creation.

content_blocks.body: Simile: 'Her smile was like sunshine.' Metaphor: 'Her smile was sunshine.' Personification: 'The drums called our feet to dance.'

classify.prompt: Label each as Simile (S), Metaphor (M), or Personification (P).

items.text: The night wrapped us in velvet.
items.label: P

items.text: Yaw is a rock in hard times.
items.label: M

items.text: The river runs like silver thread.
items.label: S

ai_task.prompt: Write 2 lines of personification about rain in Accra.

lessons.title: Sound Devices: Alliteration, Assonance, Onomatopoeia
objectives: Identify and use common sound devices.
Explain how sound supports mood or meaning.

vocabulary.definition: Repetition of initial consonant sounds (e.g., bold boys).
Repetition of vowel sounds (e.g., sweet dreams).
A word that imitates a sound (e.g., buzz, clap).

lessons.moral_link: Choose sounds that strengthen, not mock or harm.

content_blocks.body: Alliteration can make lines musical; assonance can make them smooth; onomatopoeia adds lively effects.

content_blocks.caption: Hear sound devices in short lines.

ai_task.prompt: Write a 3‑line stanza using at least one sound device.

lessons.title: Write Your Poem: Imagery & Theme
objectives: Draft an 8–12 line poem with a clear image pattern and theme.
Revise for vivid words, line breaks, and cohesion.

vocabulary.definition: Language that appeals to the senses.
Where a poet chooses to end a line.

lessons.moral_link: Let your poem lift hearts—gratitude, honesty, kindness.

content_blocks.caption: Build an imagery web (sight, sound, touch, taste, smell).

content_blocks.body: Cut weak words; prefer precise verbs and concrete nouns.

scaffold: Draft 8–12 lines using at least one simile or metaphor.
Revise line breaks for rhythm; add one sound device.

lessons.title: Performance & Reflection
objectives: Perform your poem with clear voice, pace, and feeling.
Reflect on how your poem’s theme matters at school or home.

vocabulary.definition: Speaking a poem aloud from memory or the page.
Rise and fall of the voice to show feeling.

lessons.moral_link: Share your gift humbly; encourage others.

content_blocks.body: Stand steady, breathe deeply, and speak slowly. Pause at line breaks; stress key words.

speaking_task.prompt: Record a 45–60 second performance of your poem.

reflection.prompt: In 3–4 sentences, explain your poem’s theme and one way to live it out this week.

quiz_mcq.q: A rhyme scheme of ABAB means:

options: Her eyes are stars in the night.
Her eyes shine as bright as stars.

quiz_mcq.q: The best definition of imagery is:

writing_prompt.prompt: Write an 8–12 line poem on a theme of gratitude or kindness. Include at least one simile or metaphor and one sound device.

speaking_task.prompt: Perform your poem (45–60 seconds). Focus on voice control, pauses, and feeling.

criteria.name: Theme & Cohesion
criteria.descriptor: Clear theme; lines flow logically; purposeful line breaks.

criteria.name: Mechanics (UK)
criteria.descriptor: Spelling, punctuation, and layout support meaning.

criteria.name: Clarity & Pronunciation
criteria.descriptor: Words are clear; key words stressed.
